results.headline: Review: ‘Fathers and Daughters,’ a Sappy Tale Unredeemed by Star Power
results.summary_short: Blunt dialogue and infuriatingly coy storytelling pervade this weepy melodrama starring Amanda Seyfried and Russell Crowe.

results.display_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates
results.headline: Review: ‘Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates,’ Antics to Not Love nor Cherish
results.summary_short: This aggressively stupid movie has nothing going for it other than some wasted talent.

results.display_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You
results.headline: Review: About Norman Lear, Who Gave Us Archie Bunker
results.summary_short: The documentary “Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You” is a portrait of the 1970s TV hitmaker who broke ground with issue-oriented humor.

results.headline: Review: ‘Cell’ Offers Zombified Victims and an Unfocused Narrative
results.summary_short: This film, dated, despondent and pretty much a disaster, plays like a series of nods to other science fiction-horror hybrids.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cell

results.headline: Review: ‘Cold War 2,’ a Brisk Exercise in Hong Kong Suspense
results.summary_short: This action film by Longman Leung and Sunny Luk follows the 2012 crime film “Cold War,” a tense, engaging cop thriller.

results.headline: Review: ‘The Debt’ in This Barney Elliott Film Is a Commodity
results.summary_short: Peru’s agricultural landscape is the setting for this film about corporate greed and the persistence of native farmers.

results.headline: Review: Is the Indian Point Nuclear Plant Safe? Nobody Knows
results.summary_short: The documentary “Indian Point,” directed by Ivy Meeropol, focuses on complaints about the safety of this power plant, about 45 miles from Midtown Manhattan.

results.headline: Review: ‘The Secret Life of Pets’ Amuses, but Misses Opportunities
results.summary_short: This film is clearly the work of dog people, and traffics — like nearly every other movie in its genre — in some tired anti-feline stereotypes.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Under the Sun,’ Two Views of North Korea
results.summary_short: Vitaly Mansky’s final film is something different from what his handlers in Pyongyang had in mind.

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Innocents,’ Not Even Nuns Are Spared War Horrors
results.summary_short: The film, based on real events in postwar Poland, depicts how atrocities test the faith of Catholic nuns in their own convent.

results.headline: Review: A House Car? For ‘Microbe and Gasoline,’ It’s Freedom
results.summary_short: This coming-of-age tale centers on two adolescent outsiders who hit the road in a zany homemade vehicle that doubles as a dwelling.

results.headline: Review: Once Lost, ‘Private Property’ Is a Genuine Rediscovery

results.headline: Review: A Professor Drawn to the Mob in ‘Our Kind of Traitor’

results.headline: Review: ‘The Purge: Election Year’ Offers a Campaign Platform of Blood Lust

results.headline: Review: In ‘Carnage Park,’ the Hills Have Eyes, and a Sniper, Too

results.headline: Review: In ‘Life, Animated,’ a Bound Mind Finds Freedom
results.summary_short: This documentary, based on Ron Suskind’s book, recounts how Disney films helped his autistic son learn to communicate, and explores his growing up.

results.headline: Review: Bruce Willis Is a Banker With Issues in ‘Marauders’

results.headline: Review: Revisiting an Unlikely Campaign in ‘Roseanne for President!’
results.summary_short: Eric Weinrib’s documentary is a fascinating record of Roseanne Barr’s pursuit of a spot on the Green Party’s national ticket in 2012.

results.headline: Review: A ‘Tarzan’ With a Few Twists in the Hollywood Vine

results.headline: Review: In ‘The BFG,’ Walking Gently and Wearing Huge Shoes
results.summary_short: In Steven Spielberg’s adaptation of a Roald Dahl story, restraint and Mark Rylance prevail in the face of digital wizardry and belabored wonderment.
